title: Accessibility statement for the court and tribunal hearings service

section1.text1: This accessibility statement applies to content published on
section1.text2: The court and tribunal hearings service provides a publishing platform to enable information, such as hearing lists, provided by HMCTS to be shared, displayed and updated as appropriate. It will enable information to be displayed to court users, consistent with jurisdictional procedures and business rules. The service supports HMCTS’ commitment to open justice and the provision of transparent and consistent court and tribunal information across jurisdictions
section1.text4: This website is run by HM Courts and Tribunals. We want as many people as possible to be able to use this website, so we have designed it to be accessible. For example, that means you should be able to:
section1.text5: We’ve also made the website text as simple as possible to understand.

section2.heading: How accessible this website is
section2.upperText: We know some parts of this website are not fully accessible, for example:
text: Many PDF documents published within this service are not fully accessible to screen reader software as the content is untagged, untitled and the tables are not marked up in a logical way to enable screen reader users to navigate and identify the information correctly.

The sign in and password reset pages for someone with a court and tribunal hearings account are not fully accessible to screen reader software because headings on these pages are not read out. This means screen reader users may find it hard to identify the purpose and logical structure of the page.
The colour contrast makes it hard to read text in some parts of the website.

section3.text1: If you need information on this website in a different format like accessible PDF, large print, easy read or braille, please contact:
section3.text2: We'll consider your request and get back to you within 10 working days.

section5.heading: Enforcement procedure
section5.text1: The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) is responsible for enforcing the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018 (the ‘accessibility regulations’). If you’re not happy with how we respond to your complaint,

links.text: contact the Equality Advisory and Support Service (EASS) (opens in a new window).

section6.heading: Contacting us by phone or visiting us in person
text: We provide a text relay service for people who are D/deaf, hearing impaired or have a speech impediment.
Our courts and tribunals have audio induction loops, or if you contact us before your visit we can arrange a British Sign Language (BSL) interpreter.
Find out how to contact us by using the contact details above.

section7.heading: Technical information about this website’s accessibility
section7.text1: HM Courts and Tribunal Service is committed to making its websites accessible, in accordance with the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018.

section8.heading: Compliance status
section8.text1: This website is partially compliant with the
section8.text2: AA standard, due to the non-compliances listed below.

section9.preamble: The content listed below is non-accessible for the following reasons.
text: Some hearing lists presented within the service are presented and viewable as a PDF or word document (flat files). These can be difficult for screen reader users to navigate as the content is untagged, untitled and the tables are not marked up to enable screen reader users to navigate and identify the information correctly.
This fails WCAG 2.1 A criterion 2.4.2 (page titled) and 1.3.1 (info and relationship).
Progress will be reviewed on an ongoing basis, with a full review planned for December 2022.

Sign in and forgotten password screens for a member of the media (with a court and tribunals hearings account) are not fully accessible, as headings are not read out and some images do not have alternative text.
This fails WCAG 2.1 A criterion 1.3.1 (info and relationship). The interface is based on a third party out of the box design pattern.
We will look to fix this issue by December 2022.

section10.heading: What we’re doing to improve accessibility
text: We plan to improve accessibility by proactively engaging with HMCTS’ Reform Programme to make sure that source systems produce accessible documents for publishing. We have asked services to add work to future enhancements to update the way they produce documents to make they fully accessible.
The service team has received a new version of the sign in pages to resolve the accessibility compliance issue.  This should be implemented by December 2022.
We will continually run automated accessibility testing as part of our development practices.

section11.heading: Preparation of this accessibility statement
section11.text1: This statement was prepared on 28 April 2022.  It was last reviewed on 3 May 2022.

section11.text6: This website was last tested by the Digital Accessibility Centre (DAC) on 1 March 2022 against WCAG 2.1 standards.
section11.text8: “The service is tested by a team of experienced auditors and analysts, many of who are disabled individuals and users of adaptive technology. The combination of subjective pan-disability user feedback and comprehensive technical auditing allows us to measure how the service performs technically and practically, thereby offering an essential added dimension to our test results that other methods of testing cannot provide.”
section11.text9: “Manual accessibility checking was conducted by a team of disabled individuals, using a range of adaptive technologies (hardware and software designed to facilitate the use of computers by people with disabilities).”
section11.text10: “Technical auditing involves the experienced application of a number of technical auditing and standards compliance assessment tools. This combined with an extensive knowledge of WCAG, its application and wider global practice provides the DAC website with further credibility and quality.”
